I am upgrading from a junk Kyocera hydro phone I bought on clearance from Walmart two years ago, on Black Friday.

Right away, from the getgo, this phone is amazing, Long battery life, super fast cellphone cpu, a lot of memory, and no lag or response times so far. It responds quickly, no freeze screens, power on / off / restart works fine, and I even put in a 16 gb micro sd card from my Kyocera that it recognized right away. It is also unlocked, which is nice too. I plan on traveling with it and getting a sim card from ATT up north without having to worry if it will be able to be used by that carrier or not.

If youre looking for an upgrade and having phone frustrations with an older android phone, don't hesitate, don't be the old me, upgrade. get this phone.
I stuck with a junker phone for a year and a half, hoping my phone would get better if i kept cleaning it off. All I was doing was delaying the inevitable. This Samsung J7 Prime phone is durable [Frame made out of METAL], sturdy, and amazing. and as a guy with really, big hands and not very dexterous, this phone is very easy to use for people like me. As my huge fingers and hands hit the wrong keys frequently on other phones and apps on them. This phone also comes with a 1 year warranty on select parts in the phone for manufacturer defects (6 months on certain parts from manufacturer defects also, read the manual.)
......ps (Just don't drop it....... unless you have insurance through squaretrade)

Google Apps with Android, has a cloud (storage) service. I was able to take all of the useful/borderline necessary apps/save data/etc off my old Kyocera phone, put them on the cloud, and move them over to this phone (samsung j7 prime). It took a bit of time to figure my way around, but I did it.

Cons: The only annoying part of this phone, is that to get the sim card doors open (*there are two doors. one door holds just a sim card. the other one, holds a sim card, and a micro sd card*), you have to use the tool provided. It looks like something wal mart would stick in your items in the packages, to keep you from walking out the store without paying.
Now, how samsung expects us to lug this around in my pocket without bending, breaking, or losing the flimsy thing is beyond me. But in all their wisdom, they made the doors like this. They're not the kind on some phones you'd expect where you stick your fingernail in and pop the door out. thats the only major inconvenience, right off the bat, i see with this phone. For that, I will give this review a 4 star review.

Ulasan:
Great all-around phone for the price, the battery has lasted me up to two days, it's fast, the software is clean (no bloatware!) and customisable, and it's physical characteristics are excellent. It's pleasingly slim, and the screen is large enough for anything you need it for, the dual-sim feature is incredibly useful for me as I travel frequently. I love that I can easily manage which sim card is used for either texting, calling, or data right from the drop-down menu.
For me, the biggest caveat is the lack of compass. The phone is certainly usable for directions when driving because it uses the GPS to track the motion of the car to determine your direction of travel, but if you are trying use the phone for directions while on foot, the lack of compass stands out immediately. Neither the arrow nor the map rotate with the phone when on foot making it difficult to determine which way to start walking. After using this phone over the last year, I learned to use the landmarks noted on the map as reference points, but it would be much more user-friendly if there simply was a compass built into the phone.
Ultimately, I am very happy with this phone and would buy it again, but it could be even better if a compass was added.

Update: The firm selling this phone claims the label was applied by Samsung at an overseas distribution point, after they removed the phone to activate it on the local national network. I gave the phone a shot despite my concerns and it does not work on AT&T 4g in the USA. It'll get a lower speed network, but not full 4G or LTE. AT&T worked a while trying to make it happen, but said that internally they found notes saying it is not compatible. Too bad. The seller processed a return and I bumped the review up two stars.

I wish Samsung would sell these in the USA. The reason they do not is pretty obvious: nobody would pay for the Samsung S8 if they could have a phone with these specs. There are several features on this phone not even offered on flagship phones in the USA (FM radio, sual-sim, etc.). The S* is more flashy, but it's not worth the money for what I (and most people) do.

Original Review:

Bought this "factory new" Samsung phone and it arrives with a fake tamper-evident label over the original factory tamper-evident label, which was previously cut open. The label they put on top is a smudged printed copy of the original Samsung tamper-proof label, only made larger so that it can cover the original. So this is not a one-off mistake. That label was crafted by someone specifically to cover over the factory Samsung label in order to hide tamper seals being disturbed, and I guarantee Samsung did not do it (the printing is bad, and Samsung would not cover a tamper seal with a second one after having opened the original). Again, this is not a one-off. That kind of industry - making fake tamper-proof labels - suggests to me that Mobiles International does this as routine.

Either the phone was used or the seller opened the phone to load apps or malicious code on it. Or both. Either way these guys are not legit. I processed a return, but Amazon really needs to police these sellers better an make guys like this go away.

Oh, and isn't counterfeiting tamper-evident labels using someone's graphics and copyright a federal felony?
